texts.definition: The temporary or permanent absence of a type of resource in a game.
markups: <style="Definition">The temporary or permanent absence of a type of resource in a game.</style>

Resources of various kinds are used in most games. In some games, such resources can be created or consumed and when all resources of a type have been consumed so none are available to players they experience <style="CurrentLink">Complete Resource Depletion</style>.

Players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> can experience <style="CurrentLink">Complete Resource Depletion</style> since they may lose all their pieces except for the king.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warcraft%20series">Warcraft series</link></style> provides a weaker example of <style="CurrentLink">Complete Resource Depletion</style> since all gold mines may be emptied in prolonged games, but players still have other ways of gaining more gold.

<style="CurrentLink">Complete Resource Depletion</style> is a way of designing games so specific <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> while not be available for use. However, it can be set up so it only lasts for certain periods of time.

Ensuring <style="CurrentLink">Complete Resource Depletion</style> consist of making sure existing <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> are used up quicker than new ones are acquired. This can be most surely be achieved through having <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style> together with requiring the use of <style="Link"><link="consumers">Consumers</link></style> (or having <style="Link"><link="consumers">Consumers</link></style> that players don't control that continuously use up the <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>). Just having <style="Link"><link="consumers">Consumers</link></style> and less productive <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Producers">Producers</link></style> can also work as long as the consumption can be guaranteed to be higher than the production.

<style="CurrentLink">Complete Resource Depletion</style> can create <style="Link"><link="entrenching-gameplay">Entrenching Gameplay</link></style> or initiate <style="Link"><link="endgame">Endgame</link></style> phases due to the different circumstances for gameplay when specific <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> have been exhausted. When the lack of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> make certain actions available, this may hinder competition between players and thereby force <style="Link"><link="tied-results">Tied Results</link></style>.

When the lack of certain <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> signify the end of game instances, players can use <style="CurrentLink">Complete Resource Depletion</style> as a means of causing <style="Link"><link="speedending">Speedending</link></style>.
